Sequence Information.Peptide Name: cOB1 (Val-rich; pheromone, natural AMPs; Gram-positive commensal bacteria, prokaryotes; UCLL1a)

Literature Information.Literature: Sequence analysis: APD analysis reveals that the sequence of this peptide most resembles (44.4% similarity)Baceridin. Originally identified as a sex pheromone (Nakayama J et al., 1995, Isolation and Structure of the Enterococcus faecalis Sex Pheromone, cOB1, That Induces Conjugal Transfer of the Hemolysin/Bacteriocin Plasmids, pOB1 and pYI1 (plasmid-encoded), Japan Society of Biosci. Biotech. and Agrochem, Tokyo, pp. 703-705),Activity: cOB1 of Commensal E. faecalis can restrict the growth of multidrug-resistant E. faecalis V583 (MIC 22 pg/mL) in the gut at an extremely low concentration. It can form amyloid-like structures (Gour et al., 2019).MOA:bacteria: The killing mechanism is under investigation but apparently differs from the classic AMPs that target membranes.AMP significance: This study indicates the importance of maintaining the commensal population as a means of preventing infection.Update 4/2016; 12/2024.
Literature Information.Author: Gilmore MS, Rauch M, Ramsey MM, Himes PR, Varahan S, Manson JM, Lebreton F, Hancock LE.2015
Literature Information.Reference: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2015 Jun 9;112(23):7273-8.PubMed
Literature Information.Title: Pheromone killing of multidrug-resistant Enterococcus faecalis V583 by native commensal strains
